articles.headline: Obama Backs Bill to Overhaul Immigration as Debate Is Set
articles.snippet: The Senate voted to begin debating the bipartisan immigration proposal, giving President Obama a chance to reach the kind of landmark accord with Republicans that has eluded him.
articles.abstract: The Senate voted to begin debating the bipartisan immigration proposal, giving President Obama a chance to reach the kind of landmark accord with Republicans that has eluded him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to begin debating an overhaul of the nation’s immigrations laws, President Obama offered a wholehearted endorsement of the bipartisan proposal, which presents him with a chance to reach the kind of landmark accord with Republicans that has eluded him on the budget and gun violence.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Walgreen to Pay $80 Million Fine in D.E.A. Inquiry
articles.snippet: The accord will resolve federal charges that the drugstore chain failed to properly monitor the sales of controlled drugs at some of its outlets.
articles.abstract: The accord will resolve federal charges that the drugstore chain failed to properly monitor the sales of controlled drugs at some of its outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Walgreen Company, the nation’s biggest pharmacy operator, agreed on Tuesday to pay $80 million to resolve federal charges that it failed to properly control the sales of narcotic painkillers at some of its outlets.

articles.headline: Health Care’s Overlooked Cost Factor
articles.snippet: While efforts to rein in medical costs focus on waste, hospitals’ market concentration receives less attention.
articles.abstract: While efforts to rein in medical costs focus on waste, hospitals’ market concentration receives less attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Evanston Northwestern Healthcare Corporation merged its two hospitals with the neighboring Highland Park Hospital just north of Chicago 13 years ago, the deal was presented as an opportunity to increase efficiency and improve the quality of patient care.

articles.headline: Insurers Inflating Books, New York Regulator Says
articles.snippet: New York regulators say life insurers are putting policyholders at risk and could cause another taxpayer bailout.
articles.abstract: New York regulators say life insurers are putting policyholders at risk and could cause another taxpayer bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York State regulators are calling for a nationwide moratorium on transactions that life insurers are using to alter their books by billions of dollars, saying that the deals put policyholders at risk and could lead to another taxpayer bailout.

articles.headline: In a Shift, Interest Rates Are Rising
articles.snippet: The interest rate charged by lenders has been going down for most of the time since the early 1980s, but there are signs that will not last.
articles.abstract: The interest rate charged by lenders has been going down for most of the time since the early 1980s, but there are signs that will not last.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a reliable fact of life for investors, corporations and ordinary borrowers: interest rates, for the most part, keep heading lower.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Judge Rules That Movie Studio Should Have Been Paying Interns
articles.snippet: The case could upend a long-held practice in the film industry and other businesses that rely heavily on unpaid internships.
articles.abstract: The case could upend a long-held practice in the film industry and other businesses that rely heavily on unpaid internships.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that Fox Searchlight Pictures had violated federal and New York minimum wage laws by not paying production interns, a case that could upend the long-held practice of the film industry and other businesses that rely heavily on unpaid internships.

articles.headline: Behind Cry for Help From China Labor Camp
articles.snippet: A Beijing resident and adherent of the banned Falun Gong movement said he slipped letters into product packages apparently meant for the West.
articles.abstract: A Beijing resident and adherent of the banned Falun Gong movement said he slipped letters into product packages apparently meant for the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASANJIA, China — The cry for help, a neatly folded letter stuffed inside a package of Halloween decorations sold at Kmart, traveled 5,000 miles from China into the hands of a mother of two in Oregon.

articles.headline: Voice-Activated Technology Is Called Safety Risk for Drivers
articles.snippet: Significant cognitive distraction was seen by researchers who analyzed subjects trying to juggle driving with high-tech in-car systems.
articles.abstract: Significant cognitive distraction was seen by researchers who analyzed subjects trying to juggle driving with high-tech in-car systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: As concerns have intensified about driver distraction from electronic gadgets, automakers have increasingly introduced voice-activated systems that allow drivers to keep their hands on the wheel and eyes on the road. But a new study says that the most advanced of these systems actually create a different, and worse, safety risk, by taking a driver’s mind, if not eyes, off the road.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: A Small Company’s Reality Is Altered by ABC’s ‘Shark Tank’
articles.snippet: Technology entrepreneurs turned down a “Shark Tank” investor after taping the show’s finale, but their translation business benefited from the exposure.
articles.abstract: Technology entrepreneurs turned down a “Shark Tank” investor after taping the show’s finale, but their translation business benefited from the exposure.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been about a month since ABC showed the season finale of “Shark Tank,” the reality show that gives entrepreneurs in search of financing a chance to plead their cases before five tough-talking investors, or “sharks.” At VerbalizeIt, a technology start-up that was part of this season’s final segment, the effects of the show’s appearance can already be quantified.
